awd_titl_txt: IRES: Expanding the Reach of the International Pulsar Timing Array
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Pulsar Timing Array (IPTA) is a collaboration of astronomers who will use radio telescopes to detect and study gravitational waves, a  fundamental prediction of Einstein's theory of general relativity. Gravitational waves (GW) from the merger of two stellar-mass black holes were recently detected by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO). The IPTA collaboration will detect GW from vastly larger and heavier black holes at the cores of merging galaxies, via the precise timing of cosmic clocks called radio pulsars. The astronomers anticipate that low-frequency GW will be detected within the next five years, ushering in a revolution in our understanding of the growth and structure of our Universe. U.S. undergraduate and graduate students will be fully involved in all aspects of the project. They will collaborate with prominent scientists in different countries, play a critical role in one of the potentially transformative scientific discoveries of the century, and develop global competencies to succeed in today's interconnected world.
 
The project will monitor a number of radio pulsars using a network of large radio telescopes distributed across the globe, and search for small perturbations in the arrival times of pulsar pulses due to low-frequency gravitational waves. The IPTA currently consists of consortia from Australia, Europe, and North America, using a total of seven telescopes. In order to further increase the sensitivity of the IPTA so that it can detect and, ultimately, characterize the GW universe, the collaboration will be expanded to include researchers and telescopes in China, India, and South Africa. This expansion offers the opportunity for U.S. students to gain experience in the development of pulsar timing programs in these varied countries. The IRES award will fund two undergraduate students and one graduate student to travel to all three countries for 10-week international research experiences. The undergraduate students will be drawn from a range of U.S. institutions, including minority serving institutions and those in rural areas. They will work closely with both a U.S. graduate student also trained in IPTA research and their foreign mentor and students in the host country. The students will be trained in astrophysics, big data analysis, and radio instrumentation, preparing them for a range of careers.

por.por_cntn:
The International Pulsar Timing Array (IPTA) is a world-wide collaboration which aims to use celestial clocks called pulsars to detect gravitational waves, invisible ripples in spacetime produced by accelerating massive objects. Pulsars are exotic stars which are roughly the size of a city but weigh more than the Sun, making them the densest known objects aside from black holes. They have very high magnetic fields, which produce beamed radio emission. As pulsars spin, these beams are detectable as radio pulsations, much like the pulses of light that appear to be emitted from a lighthouse. Gravitational waves change the distances between pulsars and the Earth, leading to very small perturbations in pulse arrival times that are correlated among all of the pulsars in a pulsar timing array (PTA). 

 

The goal of the IPTA is to construct a world-wide network of pulsars observed with the largest radio telescopes around the world in order to build an extremely sensitive Galactic-scale gravitational wave detector. This detector will be used to detect gravitational waves from the most massive black holes in the universe at the cores of merging galaxies. In order to succeed, it is necessary to observe pulsars distributed across the entire sky, necessitating a world-wide network of radio telescopes.

 

The IPTA was formed in 2008 as a collaboration between local collaborations in North America (NANOGrav), Australia (PPTA), and Europe (EPTA). At the beginning of this IRES project in 2017, a major goal of the IPTA was to expand through the inclusion of collaborations in China, India, and South Africa. The goal of this IRES project was to provide undergraduate students from a diverse range of institutions in the United States with the opportunity to perform IPTA-related research at a foreign site, focusing on China, India, and South Africa to build and strengthen new collaborations with those countries. 

 

This IRES award supported research experiences for 31 students from 13 institutions. Of these 33 students, 30 were undergraduate and three were graduate students. We aimed to recruit students who were traditionally under-represented in science to our program; 53% of IRES students were female, 16% were from under-represented minority groups, and 23% were first-generation college students. The students performed research at 12 sites in eight countries, including Australia (4 students), Canada (5 students), China (5 students), India (8 students), Italy (3 students), South Africa (3 students), and the United Kingdom (3 students). We supported 13 students in 2018, 11 in 2019, 2 in 2021, and 7 in 2022. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, the small 2021 cohort worked at WVU and were remotely supervised by a mentor in India. We sent no students abroad in 2020 or 2021 and in 2022 sent most students to Canada because of continued concerns about COVID-19.

 

The students performed a wide range of research projects on scientific topics such as radio instrumentation, artificial intelligence, radio pulsar observations, and numerical relativity. Students showed statistically significant gains in scientific and technical knowledge, intercultural collaboration and communication skills, and interest in working with scientists from other countries. In addition, the IRES experiences resulted in statistically significant increases in participants' interest in pursuing careers in science and technology. Finally, the IRES experiences were important for building new collaborations with China, India, and South Africa. In fact, India has now officially joined the IPTA collaboration, and South Africa will join over the next several weeks.
